pages.text: The sawmill is a machine assembly which cuts wooden logs into neatly stacked planks. The machine operates in two stages by first stripping the bark of the log and then using a $(l:patchouli:tools/buzzsaw)sawblade$() to cut the stripped log apart.

pages.name: Sawmill
pages.text: The structure is built from the following $(t:8 Steel Scaffolding Blocks, 4 Iron Sheetmetal Blocks, 6 Light Engineering Blocks, 2 Heavy Engineering Blocks, 4 Conveyor Belts, and A Redstone Engineering Block.)$(#007500)blocks$(). ($(t:Certain blocks crash if rendered in the patchouli multiblock page, in case you're wondering why I'm using this instead)$(#007500)Glazed terracotta$() in place of conveyor belts)
Both steps of the process create $(#007500)sawdust$(), which is collected and output through the port at the front of the machine. That sawdust can then be processed into paper later on.

The machine is built as shown on the first page and formed by using an $(#007500)Engineer's Hammer$() on the central sheetmetal block. $(br)Applying a redstone signal to the control panel at the front will stop the machine, this behavior can be inverted by use of the $(#007500)Engineer's Screwdriver$().

To be fully ready for processing, you will need to craft a $(l:patchouli:tools/buzzsaw)sawblade$() and insert it into the slot on the back by right-clicking. Sneak and right-click to take the sawblade out again. $(br)Running logs through the machine without a sawblade will create $(#007500)stripped logs$() that will not be cut apart. This process is much quicker than stripping them manually. $(br)The sawblade will be damaged while it's in use and may need to be replaced after a while.
